tables.table_definition: This table stores data regarding tickets(Customer queries) created by the users on the salesforce platform. Use this table only when asked about Tickets created/closed. Use the subordercode to join with oms. suborder table and then join with the sale_order table (id) to find the user id.

columns.definition: This column stores a unique identifier for a suborder associated with the case. In contexts where orders can be broken down into smaller parts (suborders) each with its specific tracking and management needs, this code helps link customer service cases to the relevant part of a larger order.
remarks: There can be multiple tickets against a single suborder code.
When the details regarding a suborder's ticket is asked, use the casenumber to identify the subordercode and then use this subordercode as a foreign key for other relevant tables.
The subordercode works as a foreign key for suborder details.

columns.definition: Records the date and time when the ticket was created in the system. This timestamp is essential for tracking the case's lifecycle, understanding response times, and managing SLAs (Service Level Agreements).
remarks: Use this date when queries about tickets created/closed are asked.
This column is already in date format so no need to convert it to any other form.

columns.definition: Indicates the most recent date and time the ticket record was updated. This could involve changing the status, adding notes, updating customer information, or any other modification. Tracking this helps in understanding the case's progress and ensures that the case data is current.
remarks: Use this column when queries about 'When it was last updated' are asked.

columns.definition: A unique identifier assigned to each ticket when it's created. This number is crucial for tracking, referencing, and managing cases within the customer service system. It allows service agents and customers to easily refer to a specific case.
remarks: When counting tickets, use the casenumber from the salesforce table.

For counting the total tickets created in a day or any specific period, you should use COUNT(DISTINCT casenumber) to ensure each ticket is counted once regardless of how many updates or changes it may have undergone during its lifecycle.

columns.definition: Reflects the current state of the case, typically indicating whether it is open, meaning active and under investigation or resolution, or closed, meaning the issue has been resolved to the customer's satisfaction or otherwise concluded. This status is key for managing the workflow of cases and prioritizing actions.
remarks: Always take status in the LOWER case when comparing it with a string.
When writing query for open tickets, use lower(status) != 'closed'
Status other than 'closed' is considered as 'open'.

columns.definition: This column is used to find the origin of the ticket(from where the ticket was created).
remarks: When asked about the origin of the ticket, use this column.
The distinct values of the origin are mentioned in the sample data column.

columns.definition: This column stores the date when the ticket was marked as 'Closed'.
remarks: Use this column when asked about closed tickets.

tables.table_definition: It contains data related to UD(undelivered), and RTO suborders. This table is used after the suborders are OFD(out for delivery).

columns.definition: The timestamp when the current status was marked.
This column stores the UD reason/code (why the suborder was marked undelivered) when the status is 'UDL'.

remarks: The courier boy was not able to find the address mentioned
When the customer directly collects an order from the warehouse.
The customer refused to accept the order.
The customer was not ready with the cash.
The given address was out of reach of the courier group.
The customer refused to accept the order.
The customer was not available at the given address
This code is marked when the customer doesn't want the product so the customer gives the OTP to the courier boy and he marks the order as RTO(return to origin)
The value is null when the suborder status is 'DEL' or 'RTO'
Use these columns when asked about undelivered reasons.

columns.definition: This column stores the courier group of the suborder. There are various courier groups.
This column stores the payment mode of the suborder. It can be cash on delivery or prepaid.
remarks: When counting tickets, use the casenumber from the salesforce table.

For counting the total tickets created in a day or any specific period, you should use COUNT(DISTINCT casenumber) to ensure each ticket is counted once regardless of how many updates or changes it may have undergone during its lifecycle.

columns.definition: This column stores a unique identifier for a suborder, in contexts where orders can be broken down into smaller parts (suborders), each with specific tracking and management needs. This column is used as a Foreign Key for suborder details.
remarks: used as a foreign key for suborder details

columns.definition: Code representing the current status of the suborder (e.g., pending, shipped, delivered).
remarks: Use RTO when asked about RTO suborders.
Used UDL when asked about undelivered suborders
Use Del when asked about delivered suborders.

columns.definition: This column gives the attempt number for that particular suborder code.

tables.table_definition: This table stores data related to each suborder. The 'code' is a unique code for each suborder. This code is used to join with other tables having a suborder_code column. Used to count Rejected orders, Duplicate orders, and suborder count. Commonly joined with sale_order to find user id(user_id).

columns.definition: Unique identifier for each suborder record.
Identifier linking the suborder to its parent order.
remarks: This column is used for joining with sale_order_vw (id).

columns.definition: Code identifying the vendor or supplier of the item.
Stock-keeping unit (SKU) unique product code for item identification.

This column stores a unique identifier for a suborder, in contexts where orders can be broken down into smaller parts (suborders), each with specific tracking and management needs. This column is used as a Foreign Key for suborder details.
remarks: used as a foreign key for suborder details

columns.definition: Code representing the current status of the suborder (e.g., pending, shipped, delivered).

remarks: Closed in lieu of a secondary suborder i.e. either reshipped, replaced, or alternate suborder
Suborder is closed for vendor reallocation to create a secondary suborder
Pending Fulfillment i.e. to be enqueued
When writing queries ,always remember to remove 'FLD' orders using status_code.
These status codes are before the order is shipped
PVF , CRD , REJ , CLD,FLD are commonly used from this column.

columns.definition: The total amount paid by the customer for the suborder.
Code identifying the shipping method used for the suborder.
remarks: Online paid orders are called prepaid orders.

tables.table_definition: This table stores Order transaction-related details. This is used to identify payment modes for a suborder.

columns.definition: Identifier linking the suborder to its parent order.

This column stores a unique identifier for a suborder in contexts where orders can be broken down into smaller parts (suborders) each with specific tracking and management needs. This column is used as a Foreign Key for suborder details.
Method of payment. The distinct values are provided in the Sample Data column.
remarks: This column is used when asked about payment_mode related problems.
There can be multiple payment modes on a single code (which is the same as a suborder_code).

columns.definition: Identifier for the payment gateway used to process the transaction.
The total amount paid in the transaction.
Code representing the status of the payment (e.g., successful, failed, pending).
Indicates whether the payment gateway has successfully captured the payment amount.
Timestamp when the transaction record was created.
Timestamp when the transaction record was last updated.
Mobile number associated with the transaction or user.
Identifier for the user who initiated the transaction. Unique id for each user.
Email address of the user associated with the transaction.
A unique identifier or code for the order possibly used for tracking or customer service purposes.
Name of the customer who placed the order.
Identifier for the user within an Inventory Management System (IMS) if integrated with the OMS. This is used as user identifier and unique to each user.
Identifier or name of the storefront or sales channel through which the order was placed. The distinct values are provided in the sample data column.

tables.table_definition: This is the primary table that logs the data when an order is placed in the system. It contains all the orders with their current status and their respective source and device type from which it was placed. This table contains 2 primary keys - id, and code which both can be used to join with other tables. It also contains the user identification (field name - ims_user_id). When using this table we need to remove the IDs which are having status FLD.

columns.definition: The primary key of the table uniquely identifies each sale order record. It's typically used for referencing orders in database operations.
remarks: This column is used in the JOIN condition with the oms.suborder on order_id.
For reference: oms.sale_order_vw so JOIN oms.suborder subo on so.id = subo.order_id.

columns.definition: This gives a unique identifier for the order in the database. It can be used when someone asks for orderCode.
Represents the lifecycle stage of the order such as 'pending', 'processing', 'shipped', 'delivered', or 'canceled'. This field helps in managing workflow and customer updates.
The full name of the customer placing the order.
It is the identification key for the user who has placed the order.
The total amount paid by the customer for the order. This includes the cost of the products, taxes, and shipping fees minus any discounts.
Indicates the sales channel (e.g., DIRECT, SNAPLITE) through which the order was placed.
remarks: It should be used in the GROUP BY clause when asked for the channel-wise analysis.

columns.definition: A datetime stamp marking when the order was initially placed is essential for order tracking, reporting, and timing-based analysis.
A datetime stamp of the last modification to the order, tracking changes over time and supporting operational management.
Associate the order with a specific shopping cart instance, linking order items and pre-purchase selections.
All the users are mapped with an ims_user_id in the database. This field indirectly gives the identification for the user who has placed the order.

tables.table_definition: This table contains information related to packages returned by customers. It includes details such as the current state of the returned package, preferred pick-up date for return, and return dates. This table should be joined after the rms_dwh.customer_returned_item table (alias cri) when used.

columns.description: The primary key of the table uniquely identifies each record of a customer review package.
remarks: This column is used to join with the rms_dwh.customer_returned_item table with the crp_id present in it.
For Reference - rms_dwh.customer_returned_item cri LEFT JOIN rms_dwh.customer_returned_package crp on cri.crp_id = crp.id

columns.description: Represents the lifecycle stage of the review package such as 'pending review', 'in transit', 'delivered', 'reviewed', or 'closed.'

Remarks: DELIVERED TO SELLER ACCORDING TO COURIER
Customer doesn't want to return the product

remarks: It gives a specific code (which has some specific meaning related to the package journey) which in returns tells us about the status of the returned item.

columns.description: Identifies the shipping provider (e.g., UPS, FedEx) by a unique code used to track which company is responsible for the delivery of the package.
Remarks: It is the code that shows which company is assigned in the return journey of the requested package.

columns.description: If the package is returned, this code indicates which returns center is handling it, which is useful for managing returns and exchanges.
A timestamp detailing when the record was first created, providing a chronological order of entries.
A timestamp of the most recent update made to the record, helping track changes over time.
Tracks how many times the pickup or delivery of the package has been rescheduled, indicating potential issues or customer preferences.
A more detailed indication of the preferred pickup time, potentially combining date and hour for precise scheduling.
A boolean flag indicates whether a specific quality control check (DSQC) has been completed, ensuring package integrity.
The date on which the current status was applied helps track progress and delays. It is an important column as it tells about when the status was updated on the returned package.
Remarks: It is the important column as it tells about when the status was updated on the returned package.

tables.table_definition: This is a view that contains data for only verified suborders. This is an important table that provides mapping for the suborder and ims_user_id (user id) and soi_shipping_package_id which is used to check further shipping-related details in the shipping tables for the suborder. This table contains only verified suborders, so when asked to find the number of suborders booked on a specific day this table should not be used as a primary table.

columns.definition: All the users are mapped with an ims_user_id in the database. This field indirectly gives the identification for the user who has placed the order.
remarks: This key can be used when asked to count the number of suborders per user or for a specific user.

columns.definition: A unique identifier for the order in the database. It can be used when someone asks for details regarding the order code.
remarks: order_code is a primary key that is created when an order is generated in a system.
This can be used with JOIN condition on oms.sale_order_vw.
For Reference: oms.sale_order_vw so JOIN dwh.f_suborders_oms_vw fso on so.code = fso.order_code

columns.definition: The name of the city entered as part of the shipping address for an order.
The postal code is associated with the shipping destination of an order.
The state, province, or region for the shipping destination.

The unique system identifier for the shipping provider or courier company responsible for delivering the order. This ID can be used to join with other tables that contain detailed information about the shipping providers.
Remarks: This column is used to join with the table cg. It is used to know the further journey when the order is shipped.
For Reference : dwh.f_suborders_oms_vw fso JOIN analytics_logistics.courier_Group cg on cg.shipping_provider_sid = fso.shipping_provider_sid

columns.definition: It could represent the amount of 'snapcash' (a digital currency that is used on the platform) used or credited in a transaction.
Stands for 'Suborder Item Shipping Package ID'. This ID helps to track the package throughout the shipping process and is essential for inventory control and customer service inquiries.
remarks: This column is used to join with table dwh.f_shipping_package_vw (alias - fsp).
For Reference: dwh.f_suborders_oms_vw fso JOIN dwh.f_shipping_package_vw on fso.soi_shipping_package_id = fsp.sp_shipping_package_id

columns.definition: The timestamp of when the suborder was initially entered into the system.
Remarks: Convert this field in YYYY-MM-DD format using to_date(subo_date_created::varchar'YYYYMMDD').

columns.definition: The date on which the suborder is delivered to the customer.
Remarks: Convert this field in YYYY-MM-DD format using to_date(subo_date_delivered::varchar'YYYYMMDD').

columns.definition: This field contains the date at which the suborder was verified in the system.
Remarks: Convert this field in YYYY-MM-DD format using to_date(subo_date_verified::varchar'YYYYMMDD').

columns.definition: This column stores a unique identifier for a suborder in contexts where orders can be broken down into smaller parts (suborders) each with specific tracking and management needs. This column is used as a Foreign Key for suborder details.
remarks: Used for joining with more tables which contains suborder_code field in themselves.
For Reference: oms.suborder subo JOIN dwh.f_suborders_oms_vw fso on fso.suborder_code = subo.code

columns.definition: System identifier for the product unique across the database for referencing the product in system-level operations.
remarks: Used to join with table dwh.d_product.
For reference: dwh.d_product dp1 on dp1.product_sid=fso.product_sid
